questions.stem: Equine infectious anemia (EIA) is BEST described as:

options.label: A
options.text: A highly contagious respiratory disease of equids caused by an orthomyxovirus

options.label: B
options.text: A noncontagious infectious disease of equids caused by a lentivirus, characterized by lifelong infection

options.label: C
options.text: A bacterial septicemia of equids caused by blood‑borne spirochetes

options.label: D
options.text: A prion disease of equids with progressive neurologic signs

questions.explanation: EIA is a noncontagious infectious disease of equids caused by equine infectious anemia virus, a lentivirus that establishes lifelong infection with recurrent viremia. It is not a highly contagious respiratory disease (A), bacterial septicemia (C), or a prion disease (D).

questions.stem: The causative agent of EIA belongs to which viral family and genus?

options.label: A
options.text: Paramyxoviridae, Morbillivirus

options.label: B
options.text: Retroviridae, Lentivirus

options.label: C
options.text: Herpesviridae, Alphaherpesvirus

options.label: D
options.text: Flaviviridae, Flavivirus

questions.explanation: EIAV is an RNA virus in the family Retroviridae, genus Lentivirus, which includes other persistent, slow viruses. The other families and genera (A, C, D) do not describe EIAV.

questions.stem: Which statement about environmental stability and disinfection of EIAV is MOST accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: EIAV is highly resistant and survives most common disinfectants

options.label: B
options.text: EIAV is inactivated only by strong oxidizing agents

options.label: C
options.text: EIAV is readily inactivated by most common disinfectants

options.label: D
options.text: EIAV forms spores that persist for months in the environment

questions.explanation: EIAV is relatively labile and is readily inactivated by most common disinfectants, so basic hygiene and disinfection are effective. It is not highly resistant or spore‑forming (A, D), and does not require only extreme disinfectants (B).

questions.stem: Which cells are primarily infected by EIAV, leading to lifelong infection?

options.label: A
options.text: Neutrophils and eosinophils

options.label: B
options.text: Monocytes and macrophages

options.label: C
options.text: Hepatocytes and biliary epithelium

options.label: D
options.text: Neurons and oligodendrocytes

questions.explanation: EIAV infects monocytes and replicates when they differentiate into macrophages, leading to viremia and immune‑mediated disease. Neutrophils (A), hepatocytes (C), and neurons (D) are not the main target cells described.

questions.stem: Which pathophysiologic effect is MOST directly associated with EIAV‑infected macrophages and their cytokine release?

options.label: A
options.text: Hyperinsulinemia and laminitis

options.label: B
options.text: Increased TNF‑α, IL‑1, IL‑6, and TGF‑β causing fever, thrombocytopenia, and inhibition of erythropoiesis

options.label: C
options.text: Excess cortisol production leading to immunosuppression

options.label: D
options.text: Direct myelin destruction producing peripheral neuropathy

questions.explanation: Infection of macrophages alters host gene expression, increasing cytokines such as TNF‑α, IL‑1, IL‑6, and TGF‑β, which trigger fever, contribute to thrombocytopenia, and inhibit erythropoiesis, worsening anemia. Hyperinsulinemia (A), cortisol excess (C), and primary myelin destruction (D) are not central mechanisms in EIA.

questions.stem: Immune‑mediated destruction of which components is a major contributor to anemia and organ enlargement in EIA?

options.label: A
options.text: IgE‑coated mast cells

options.label: B
options.text: IgG/IgM‑coated platelets and virus‑bound red blood cells

options.label: C
options.text: Free hemoglobin in plasma

options.label: D
options.text: Activated neutrophils in circulation

questions.explanation: Immune‑mediated destruction of IgG/IgM‑coated platelets and virus‑bound red blood cells causes thrombocytopenia, anemia, splenomegaly, and hepatomegaly. Mast cells (A), free hemoglobin (C), and neutrophils (D) are not the primary targets highlighted.

questions.stem: Chronic immune complex deposition in EIA is MOST likely to cause which lesions?

options.label: A
options.text: Myocarditis and endocarditis only

options.label: B
options.text: Vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and edema

options.label: C
options.text: Myositis and osteomyelitis

options.label: D
options.text: Encephalitis and meningitis

questions.explanation: Immune complexes formed during EIA can deposit in vessels and kidneys, leading to vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and edema. The other options (A, C, D) list lesions not emphasized as typical outcomes of immune complex deposition in this disease.

questions.stem: Frequent antigenic variation of EIAV primarily results in:

options.label: A
options.text: Rapid viral clearance and lifelong immunity

options.label: B
options.text: Recurrent febrile episodes and persistence as an inapparent carrier that may relapse under stress

options.label: C
options.text: Failure of the virus to establish infection

options.label: D
options.text: Development of protective cross‑neutralizing antibodies against all strains

questions.explanation: Frequent antigenic variation of EIAV allows immune escape, causing recurrent fever and eventually an inapparent carrier state that can relapse under stress. It does not promote rapid clearance (A), failure of infection (C), or universal cross‑protection (D).

questions.stem: Regarding host range and susceptibility, which statement is MOST correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Only horses are susceptible; donkeys and mules are naturally resistant

options.label: B
options.text: All equids, including horses, ponies, donkeys, mules, and zebras, are susceptible

options.label: C
options.text: Only donkeys and zebras are naturally susceptible

options.label: D
options.text: Only young foals develop clinical disease

questions.explanation: All equids, including horses, ponies, donkeys, mules, and zebras, are susceptible to EIA. Donkeys and mules are not resistant (A), and susceptibility is not restricted to certain species or ages (C, D).

questions.stem: Which species are MOST likely to show overt, severe clinical disease with EIA?

options.label: A
options.text: Donkeys and mules

options.label: B
options.text: Ponies and horses

options.label: C
options.text: Zebras only

options.label: D
options.text: All species show equal severity

questions.explanation: Horses and ponies tend to develop more overt or severe clinical disease, while donkeys and mules are more likely to have subclinical or inapparent infections. Thus, option A is incorrect, and C–D do not reflect the described species differences.

questions.stem: Which clinical form of EIA can cause death within 1–3 days, sometimes before diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Inapparent carrier form

options.label: B
options.text: Chronic form

options.label: C
options.text: Acute/peracute form

options.label: D
options.text: Subacute respiratory form

questions.explanation: The acute/peracute form may last only 1–3 days and can be fatal before diagnosis, with sudden collapse or death. The chronic (B) and inapparent (A) forms are more prolonged, and a “subacute respiratory form” (D) is not a classic category.

questions.stem: Which combination of signs is MOST typical of the acute/peracute form of EIA?

options.label: A
options.text: High fever, severe thrombocytopenia, anemia, hemorrhages, collapse or sudden death

options.label: B
options.text: Chronic cough, nasal discharge, and dyspnea only

options.label: C
options.text: Colic, diarrhea, and dehydration only

options.label: D
options.text: Ataxia, seizures, and blindness

questions.explanation: Acute/peracute EIA is characterized by high fever (up to 41°C), severe thrombocytopenia and anemia, depression, weakness, tachycardia, tachypnea, hemorrhages, and possible collapse or sudden death. Purely respiratory signs (B), gastrointestinal signs (C), or neurologic signs (D) do not describe the typical acute presentation.

questions.stem: The chronic form of EIA is BEST characterized by:

options.label: A
options.text: A single prolonged febrile episode followed by full recovery

options.label: B
options.text: Recurrent febrile episodes with thrombocytopenia, progressive weight loss, edema, and organomegaly

options.label: C
options.text: Only subclinical laboratory changes without observable signs

options.label: D
options.text: Acute neurologic deterioration with head pressing

questions.explanation: The chronic form has recurrent febrile episodes with thrombocytopenia, progressive weight loss, weakness, depression, ventral/subcutaneous edema, jaundice, and organomegaly. A single episode with full recovery (A), silent laboratory changes only (C), or acute neurologic dysfunction (D) are not characteristic.

questions.stem: The inapparent (subclinical) carrier state in EIA is characterized by:

options.label: A
options.text: Complete viral clearance and no risk of transmission

options.label: B
options.text: Lifelong infection with possible mild fever, anemia, or thrombocytopenia under stress

options.label: C
options.text: Short‑term viremia that resolves in weeks

options.label: D
options.text: Clinical disease only during winter months

questions.explanation: Inapparent carriers show no obvious signs most of the time but remain viremic and infectious for life; under stress or concurrent disease they may show mild fever, anemia, or thrombocytopenia. The virus is not cleared (A), and infection is not short‑term (C) or seasonally restricted (D).

questions.stem: Which gross lesions are MOST likely in an acute fatal case of EIA?

options.label: A
options.text: Severe pneumonia and pleural effusion

options.label: B
options.text: Splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, enlarged abdominal lymph nodes, dependent edema, mucosal hemorrhages

options.label: C
options.text: Cerebral edema and herniation

options.label: D
options.text: Gastric ulcers and intestinal torsion

questions.explanation: Acute fatal EIA commonly shows splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, enlarged abdominal lymph nodes, dependent edema, and mucosal hemorrhages. The other options (A, C, D) describe lesions not typical of EIA’s acute gross pathology.

questions.stem: What is the PRIMARY natural route of transmission of EIAV between horses?

options.label: A
options.text: Aerosol spread over short distances

options.label: B
options.text: Direct nose‑to‑nose contact with nasal secretions

options.label: C
options.text: Mechanical transmission of infected blood by biting flies such as horseflies and deerflies

options.label: D
options.text: Ingestion of contaminated feed and water

questions.explanation: The principal natural route of transmission is mechanical transfer of infected blood on the mouthparts of biting flies, especially horseflies and deerflies. Aerosol (A), direct respiratory contact (B), or ingestion (D) are not primary mechanisms.

questions.stem: Which statement about iatrogenic transmission of EIA is MOST accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Iatrogenic transmission does not occur

options.label: B
options.text: It can occur via contaminated needles, syringes, blood products, or surgical/dental instruments

options.label: C
options.text: It only occurs via contaminated fecal material

options.label: D
options.text: It is limited to transmission through hoof trimming tools

questions.explanation: Iatrogenic transmission can occur via contaminated needles, syringes, IV sets, blood transfusions, or inadequately disinfected surgical/dental instruments. It is not limited to fecal contamination (C) or hoof tools (D), and it certainly can occur (A).

questions.stem: In endemic, swampy regions, EIA risk is increased by:

options.label: A
options.text: Low fly presence and arid climate

options.label: B
options.text: Dense biting fly populations and high equid density, with shared or unsterile equipment

options.label: C
options.text: Absence of equids and intensive fly control

options.label: D
options.text: Exclusive housing of horses indoors with screened stalls

questions.explanation: High densities of biting flies and equids, use of shared or unsterile equipment, and poor pasture management that promotes fly contact all increase EIA risk in endemic swampy regions. Low fly presence (A), absence of equids (C), or strict indoor housing with screening (D) reduce, not increase, risk.

questions.stem: What is the MAIN diagnostic approach for confirming EIA infection in horses?

options.label: A
options.text: Fecal culture for the virus

options.label: B
options.text: Serologic testing to detect antibodies against EIAV

options.label: C
options.text: Skin scraping and cytology

options.label: D
options.text: Liver biopsy and histopathology only

questions.explanation: Diagnosis is primarily based on serologic testing to detect antibodies against EIAV; clinical signs are nonspecific. Fecal culture (A), skin scraping (C), or liver biopsy alone (D) are not standard diagnostic approaches.

questions.stem: Which serologic test is considered the internationally recognized gold standard confirmatory test for EIA?

options.label: A
options.text: Competitive ELISA

options.label: B
options.text: Western blot

options.label: C
options.text: Agar gel immunodiffusion (AGID, Coggins test)

options.label: D
options.text: Hemagglutination inhibition test

questions.explanation: The agar gel immunodiffusion test (AGID or Coggins test) is the gold standard, internationally recognized confirmatory test for EIA. ELISA (A) is a rapid screening tool that may require confirmation, and Western blot (B) is supplemental.

questions.stem: A screening ELISA test for EIA comes back positive in a clinically normal horse. The MOST appropriate next step is to:

options.label: A
options.text: Declare the horse negative and ignore the result

options.label: B
options.text: Confirm the result with an AGID (Coggins) test due to risk of false positives

options.label: C
options.text: Immediately release the horse for travel and competition

options.label: D
options.text: Treat the horse with antiviral drugs and then retest

questions.explanation: Because EIA ELISAs are sensitive but can yield false positives, any positive ELISA should be confirmed with an AGID (Coggins) test. Declaring the horse negative (A) or proceeding with normal movement (C) is unsafe, and there is no antiviral therapy to clear infection (D).

questions.stem: Which statement about treatment of EIA is MOST accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Antiviral drugs can eliminate EIAV and reverse the carrier state

options.label: B
options.text: There is no specific treatment or cure; supportive care may help acutely ill horses but does not clear infection

options.label: C
options.text: Early antibiotic therapy is curative if started within 48 hours

options.label: D
options.text: Corticosteroids reliably eliminate the virus

questions.explanation: There is no specific treatment or cure for EIA; supportive therapy may help acutely ill horses but does not eliminate EIAV or the carrier state. Antivirals (A), antibiotics (C), or corticosteroids (D) are not curative.

questions.stem: Recommended management options for horses that test positive for EIA include:

options.label: A
options.text: Free movement and sale without restriction

options.label: B
options.text: Euthanasia or strict lifelong quarantine at least ~200 m from other equids with vector control

options.label: C
options.text: Short‑term isolation followed by return to the herd

options.label: D
options.text: Vaccination and then return to normal use

questions.explanation: Management options for EIA‑positive horses are euthanasia or strict lifelong quarantine at least about 200 m from other equids under tight vector control. Unrestricted movement or sale (A), brief isolation (C), or vaccination (D) are not appropriate.

questions.stem: Which statement about prevention and control of EIA is MOST correct?

options.label: A
options.text: An effective vaccine is widely available and used in endemic areas

options.label: B
options.text: Prevention relies on regular testing, biosecurity, vector control, and regulatory measures for positive animals

options.label: C
options.text: Once a horse is infected, routine testing is unnecessary

options.label: D
options.text: Vector control has no impact on EIA transmission risk

questions.explanation: Because there is no vaccine, prevention relies on regular testing and surveillance, quarantine and testing of new arrivals, biosecurity (clean needles, disinfection, safe blood products), fly control, and regulatory restrictions on positive animals. An effective vaccine (A) does not exist, and ignoring testing (C) or vector control (D) is unsafe.

questions.stem: Regarding public health, which statement is TRUE about EIA?

options.label: A
options.text: EIAV is a significant zoonosis commonly transmitted to humans

options.label: B
options.text: Human infection is possible but usually asymptomatic

options.label: C
options.text: There is no evidence that EIA is transmissible to humans

options.label: D
options.text: People with immunosuppression are at high risk of EIA

questions.explanation: There is no evidence that EIAV is zoonotic or transmissible to humans, so it is not a recognized public health threat. Therefore, options A, B, and D are incorrect.
